<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===- Attributor.h --- Module-wide attribute deduction ---------&#42;- C++ -&#42;-===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Attributor: An inter procedural (abstract) &quot;attribute&quot; deduction framework.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The Attributor framework is an inter procedural abstract analysis (fixpoint</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// iteration analysis). The goal is to allow easy deduction of new attributes as</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// well as information exchange between abstract attributes in-flight.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The Attributor class is the driver and the link between the various abstract</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// attributes. The Attributor will iterate until a fixpoint state is reached by</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// all abstract attributes in-flight, or until it will enforce a pessimistic fix</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// point because an iteration limit is reached.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Abstract attributes, derived from the AbstractAttribute class, actually</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// describe properties of the code. They can correspond to actual LLVM-IR</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// attributes, or they can be more general, ultimately unrelated to LLVM-IR</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// attributes. The latter is useful when an abstract attributes provides</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// information to other abstract attributes in-flight but we might not want to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// manifest the information. The Attributor allows to query in-flight abstract</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// attributes through the &#96;Attributor::getAAFor&#96; method (see the method</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// description for an example). If the method is used by an abstract attribute</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// P, and it results in an abstract attribute Q, the Attributor will</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// automatically capture a potential dependence from Q to P. This dependence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// will cause P to be reevaluated whenever Q changes in the future.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The Attributor will only reevaluate abstract attributes that might have</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// changed since the last iteration. That means that the Attribute will not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// revisit all instructions/blocks/functions in the module but only query</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// an update from a subset of the abstract attributes.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The update method &#96;AbstractAttribute::updateImpl&#96; is implemented by the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// specific &quot;abstract attribute&quot; subclasses. The method is invoked whenever the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// currently assumed state (see the AbstractState class) might not be valid</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// anymore. This can, for example, happen if the state was dependent on another</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// abstract attribute that changed. In every invocation, the update method has</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to adjust the internal state of an abstract attribute to a point that is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// justifiable by the underlying IR and the current state of abstract attributes</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// in-flight. Since the IR is given and assumed to be valid, the information</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// derived from it can be assumed to hold. However, information derived from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// other abstract attributes is conditional on various things. If the justifying</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// state changed, the &#96;updateImpl&#96; has to revisit the situation and potentially</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// find another justification or limit the optimistic assumes made.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Change is the key in this framework. Until a state of no-change, thus a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// fixpoint, is reached, the Attributor will query the abstract attributes</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// in-flight to re-evaluate their state. If the (current) state is too</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// optimistic, hence it cannot be justified anymore through other abstract</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00054" /><CodeLine lineNumber="54"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// attributes or the state of the IR, the state of the abstract attribute will</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00055" /><CodeLine lineNumber="55"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// have to change. Generally, we assume abstract attribute state to be a finite</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00056" /><CodeLine lineNumber="56"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// height lattice and the update function to be monotone. However, these</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00057" /><CodeLine lineNumber="57"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// conditions are not enforced because the iteration limit will guarantee</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00058" /><CodeLine lineNumber="58"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// termination. If an optimistic fixpoint is reached, or a pessimistic fix</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00059" /><CodeLine lineNumber="59"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// point is enforced after a timeout, the abstract attributes are tasked to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00060" /><CodeLine lineNumber="60"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// manifest their result in the IR for passes to come.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00061" /><CodeLine lineNumber="61"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00062" /><CodeLine lineNumber="62"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Attribute manifestation is not mandatory. If desired, there is support to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00063" /><CodeLine lineNumber="63"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// generate a single or multiple LLVM-IR attributes already in the helper struct</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00064" /><CodeLine lineNumber="64"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// IRAttribute. In the simplest case, a subclass inherits from IRAttribute with</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00065" /><CodeLine lineNumber="65"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// a proper Attribute::AttrKind as template parameter. The Attributor</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00066" /><CodeLine lineNumber="66"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// manifestation framework will then create and place a new attribute if it is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00067" /><CodeLine lineNumber="67"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// allowed to do so (based on the abstract state). Other use cases can be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00068" /><CodeLine lineNumber="68"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// achieved by overloading AbstractAttribute or IRAttribute methods.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00069" /><CodeLine lineNumber="69"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00070" /><CodeLine lineNumber="70"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00071" /><CodeLine lineNumber="71"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The &quot;mechanics&quot; of adding a new &quot;abstract attribute&quot;:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00072" /><CodeLine lineNumber="72"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Define a class (transitively) inheriting from AbstractAttribute and one</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00073" /><CodeLine lineNumber="73"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   (which could be the same) that (transitively) inherits from AbstractState.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00074" /><CodeLine lineNumber="74"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   For the latter, consider the already available BooleanState and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00075" /><CodeLine lineNumber="75"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   &#123;Inc,Dec,Bit&#125;IntegerState if they fit your needs, e.g., you require only a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00076" /><CodeLine lineNumber="76"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   number tracking or bit-encoding.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00077" /><CodeLine lineNumber="77"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Implement all pure methods. Also use overloading if the attribute is not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00078" /><CodeLine lineNumber="78"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   conforming with the &quot;default&quot; behavior: A (set of) LLVM-IR attribute(s) for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00079" /><CodeLine lineNumber="79"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   an argument, call site argument, function return value, or function. See</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00080" /><CodeLine lineNumber="80"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   the class and method descriptions for more information on the two</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00082" /><CodeLine lineNumber="82"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Register opportunities for the new abstract attribute in the</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01498" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1498"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The fixpoint analysis framework that orchestrates the attribute deduction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01499" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1499"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01500" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1500"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The Attributor provides a general abstract analysis framework (guided</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01501" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1501"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// fixpoint iteration) as well as helper functions for the deduction of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01502" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1502"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// (LLVM-IR) attributes. However, also other code properties can be deduced,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01503" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1503"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// propagated, and ultimately manifested through the Attributor framework. This</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01504" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1504"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// is particularly useful if these properties interact with attributes and a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01505" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1505"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// co-scheduled deduction allows to improve the solution. Even if not, thus if</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01506" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1506"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// attributes/properties are completely isolated, they should use the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01507" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1507"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Attributor framework to reduce the number of fixpoint iteration frameworks</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01508" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1508"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// in the code base. Note that the Attributor design makes sure that isolated</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01509" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1509"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// attributes are not impacted, in any way, by others derived at the same time</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01510" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1510"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// if there is no cross-reasoning performed.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01511" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1511"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01512" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1512"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The public facing interface of the Attributor is kept simple and basically</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01513" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1513"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// allows abstract attributes to one thing, query abstract attributes</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01514" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1514"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// in-flight. There are two reasons to do this:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01515" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1515"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///    a) The optimistic state of one abstract attribute can justify an</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01516" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1516"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       optimistic state of another, allowing to framework to end up with an</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01517" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1517"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       optimistic (=best possible) fixpoint instead of one based solely on</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01518" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1518"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       information in the IR.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01519" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1519"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///    b) This avoids reimplementing various kinds of lookups, e.g., to check</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01520" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1520"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       for existing IR attributes, in favor of a single lookups interface</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01521" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1521"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       provided by an abstract attribute subclass.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01522" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1522"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01523" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1523"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// NOTE: The mechanics of adding a new &quot;concrete&quot; abstract attribute are</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l03250" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3250"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Base struct for all &quot;concrete attribute&quot; deductions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03251" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3251"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03252" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3252"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The abstract attribute is a minimal interface that allows the Attributor to</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03253" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3253"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// orchestrate the abstract/fixpoint analysis. The design allows to hide away</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03254" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3254"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// implementation choices made for the subclasses but also to structure their</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03255" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3255"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// implementation and simplify the use of other abstract attributes in-flight.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03256" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3256"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03257" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3257"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// To allow easy creation of new attributes, most methods have default</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03258" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3258"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// implementations. The ones that do not are generally straight forward, except</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03259" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3259"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// &#96;AbstractAttribute::updateImpl&#96; which is the location of most reasoning</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03260" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3260"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// associated with the abstract attribute. The update is invoked by the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03261" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3261"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Attributor in case the situation used to justify the current optimistic</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03262" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3262"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// state might have changed. The Attributor determines this automatically</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03263" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3263"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// by monitoring the &#96;Attributor::getAAFor&#96; calls made by abstract attributes.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03264" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3264"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03265" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3265"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The &#96;updateImpl&#96; method should inspect the IR and other abstract attributes</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3266"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// in-flight to justify the best possible (=optimistic) state. The actual</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3267"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// implementation is, similar to the underlying abstract state encoding, not</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3268"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// exposed. In the most common case, the &#96;updateImpl&#96; will go through a list of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03269" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3269"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// reasons why its optimistic state is valid given the current information. If</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3270"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// any combination of them holds and is sufficient to justify the current</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3271"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// optimistic state, the method shall return UNCHAGED. If not, the optimistic</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03272" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3272"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// state is adjusted to the situation and the method shall return CHANGED.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03273" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3273"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03274" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3274"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// If the manifestation of the &quot;concrete attribute&quot; deduced by the subclass</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03275" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3275"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// differs from the &quot;default&quot; behavior, which is a (set of) LLVM-IR</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3276"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// attribute(s) for an argument, call site argument, function return value, or</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3277"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// function, the &#96;AbstractAttribute::manifest&#96; method should be overloaded.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3278"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3279"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// NOTE: If the state obtained via getState() is INVALID, thus if</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3280"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       AbstractAttribute::getState().isValidState() returns false, no</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3281"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       information provided by the methods of this class should be used.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3282"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// NOTE: The Attributor currently has certain limitations to what we can do.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3283"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       As a general rule of thumb, &quot;concrete&quot; abstract attributes should &#42;for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3284"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       now&#42; only perform &quot;backward&quot; information propagation. That means</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3285"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       optimistic information obtained through abstract attributes should</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03286" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3286"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       only be used at positions that precede the origin of the information</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03287" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3287"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       with regards to the program flow. More practically, information can</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03288" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3288"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       &#42;now&#42; be propagated from instructions to their enclosing function, but</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03289" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3289"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       &#42;not&#42; from call sites to the called function. The mechanisms to allow</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03290" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3290"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       both directions will be added in the future.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03291" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3291"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// NOTE: The mechanics of adding a new &quot;concrete&quot; abstract attribute are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03292" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3292"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///       described in the file comment.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l05239" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5239"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// This AA collects potential values for each IR position.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l05240" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5240"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// An assumed set of potential values is initialized with the empty set (the</span></CodeLine>
